div.p: We present the 45-yr record of EXÂ Hyaâ€™s lightcurve and discuss the characteristics of its 15 observed outbursts. We then concentrate on the 1998 outburst, reporting the first outburst X-ray observations. We discover an X-ray beat-cycle modulation, indicating that an enhanced accretion stream couples directly with the magnetosphere in outburst, confirming our previous prediction. Optical eclipse profiles late in outburst show that the visible light is dominated by an enhanced mass-transfer stream overflowing the accretion disc. We are uncertain whether the enhanced mass transfer is triggered by a disc instability, or by some other cause. While in outburst, EXÂ HyaÂ shows some of the characteristics of SWÂ Sex stars.

div.p: If intermediate polars (IPs) are cataclysmic variables possessing partial accretion discs, with the centre disrupted by a magnetic field, then we expect that they can show disc instability outbursts, as dwarf novae do. Several IPs â€” XYÂ Ari (Hellier, Mukai &Â Beardmore 1997), YY Dra (Patterson etâ€‰al.Â 1992) and GKÂ Per (e.g.Â Kim etâ€‰al.Â 1992) â€” appear to show just that.

However, two other IPs â€” V1223Â Sgr &Â TVÂ Col â€” show short, low-amplitude outbursts that are unlike dwarf nova eruptions and probably result from another instability such as mass-transfer bursts (see Warner 1996 and Hellier etâ€‰al.Â 1997 for reviews). The outbursts of TVÂ Col last âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,8 h with 2-mag amplitudes (Szkody &Â Mateo 1984; Schwarz etâ€‰al.Â 1988; Hellier &Â Buckley 1993); increased S-wave emission during this period points to enhanced mass transfer. V1223Â Sgr has shown a very similar event (van Amerongen &Â van Paradijs 1989). Since these two stars have novalike discs (e.g.Â TV Col shows superhumps and V1223Â Sgr shows VYÂ Scl low states) the outbursts are unlikely to be thermal instabilities in the disc. Very similar short-lived flare events have been seen in AMÂ Her stars (e.g.Â Warren etâ€‰al.Â 1993), which cannot be disc instabilities since such stars donâ€™t have discs. [The possible IP RXâ€‰J0757+6306 may be a similar system (Tovmassian etâ€‰al.Â 1998; Kato 1999), but the data are currently too sparse for certainty.]

The remaining IP showing outbursts, EXÂ Hya, is intermediate between the above two types, with outbursts lasting âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,2â€“3 d (cf.Â 0.5 d for TVÂ Col &Â V1223Â Sgr, and 5 d for XYÂ Ari &Â YYÂ Dra). Previous outbursts have been reported by Bond etâ€‰al.Â (1987); Hellier etâ€‰al.Â (1989; hereafter PaperÂ 1); Reinsch &Â Beuermann (1990) and Buckley &Â Schwarzenberg-Czerny (1993).

div.p: A major finding from the 1987 outburst (PaperÂ 1) was a high-velocity feature in the emission-line wings. This seemed to arise from an enhanced accretion stream overflowing the disc and connecting directly with the magnetosphere. We predicted that since the stream rotated with the orbital frequency (Î©Î©Omega\Omega) and the magnetosphere with the spin frequency (Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega), the relative geometry (and thus the X-ray emission from stream-fed accretion) should vary at the Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omegaâ€‰-ADDOP:minus-â€‰Î©Î©Omega\OmegaÂ frequency. Such X-ray beat modulations have since been seen in many IPs (e.g.Â Hellier 1998) but not, so far, in EXÂ Hya. Accordingly, we applied for Target of Opportunity time to observe the next outburst of EXÂ Hya with the rapid-response RXTEÂ X-ray satellite. This was successfully triggered during an outburst in 1998 August and we report the results here.

EXÂ Hya is also well studied in quiescence, showing a prominent sinusoidal modulation at the 67-min spin period and a grazing eclipse recurring with the 98-min orbital period. See, e.g., Hellier (1987, hereafter PaperÂ 2) for spectroscopy, Siegel etâ€‰al.Â (1989) for optical photometry, and Rosen etâ€‰al.Â (1991) for X-ray data.

Since EXÂ Hyaâ€™s behaviour is clearly different from that of normal dwarf novae it is worth presenting the complete record. Fig.Â 1 shows the visual estimates of EXÂ HyaÂ compiled by the Variable Star Section of the RASNZ. While EXÂ HyaÂ mostly sits at 13ththFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:th FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\mbox{{\scriptsize th}}}Â mag, it rises to mag 9.5 in infrequent outbursts lasting 2â€“3 d. Note that much of the variability at quiescence is real, caused by the spin and orbital modulations. Fig.Â 2 contains details of the outbursts on an expanded scale. We note the following points:

15 outbursts have been seen in 44 years, for an average recurrence of â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰3 yrs. However, the yearly and monthly data gaps mean that many will have been missed. Coverage dense enough to catch 2-d outbursts is â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰2/3rdsrdsFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:rds FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\mbox{{\scriptsize rds}}}Â complete in recent times, dropping to â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰1/3rdrdFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:rd FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\mbox{{\scriptsize rd}}}Â complete earlier, so we can estimate that only â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰half the outbursts have been caught, reducing the recurrence to â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰1.5 yrs.

The outbursts occur irregularly: near JD 244â€‰8370 a â€˜doubleâ€™ outburst occurred with an interval of only 8 d. In contrast, taking the sampling into consideration, there is a 95%Â probability that inter-outburst intervals >RELOP:greater-than>â€‰2.7 yrs have occurred (most likely in the 12-yr period between JD 244â€‰2300â€“244â€‰6600 when no outburst was seen).

div.p: The outburst rises are unresolved in the RASNZ data, where rises of 3.4 mags in âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim <RELOP:less-than<â€‰12 hrs are seen. Reinsch &Â Beuermann (1990) caught part of a rise, seeing the brightness increase by a factor 10 within 3 hrs.
The declines are slower than the rises and are variable: the outburst at JD 244â€‰6920 declined by 3.5 mags in 1.8 d while that at JD 245â€‰1040 took 3.0 d to decline by the same amount.

div.p: The outburst at JD 244â€‰8760 was peculiar. EXÂ HyaÂ rose from mag 13.1 to 9.9 in <RELOP:less-than<â€‰15 hrs and declined from 10.3 to 12.6 in only <RELOP:less-than<â€‰4.5 hrs, the whole event being over in <RELOP:less-than<â€‰1 d. [The two outburst points are by different observers; the observers involved (including the current authors AJ and DO) are highly experienced observers of EXÂ Hya, and the data points have been confirmed from the original observing logs.]

If the accretion rate scales as the optical magnitude and if the quiescent accretion rate is âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,101616FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:16 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{16} gâ€‰sâ€“1â€“1FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:â€“1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\mbox{{\scriptsize--1}}}Â then the outbursts typically involve âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,102222FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:22 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{22} g of material.
The August 1998 outburst (Fig.Â 3) showed the usual unresolved rise but decayed to quiescence in 3 d, 1 d longer than the other well-studied outbursts.

Following notification of the outburst we observed EXÂ HyaÂ with RXTEÂ [see Bradt, Rothschild &Â Swank (1993) for a description of this satellite] gaining three sections of data on the outburst decline (Fig.Â 3). The first section, lasting 1 hr, recorded a 2â€“15 â€‰keVÂ count rate varying between 70 and 330 câ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â (all 5 PCUs); during the second section, lasting 9 hr, the count rate was in the range 60â€“220; and by the third section, lasting 6 hr, the count rate had declined to 35â€“70, essentially a quiescent count rate.

We Fourier transformed the 2â€“15 â€‰keVÂ X-ray dataset, first normalizing the three data sections to the same count rate. The result (Fig.Â 4) reveals power at the spin frequency (Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega) and at the beat frequency between the orbital and spin periods (Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omegaâ€‰-ADDOP:minus-â€‰Î©Î©Omega\Omega). An X-ray beat frequency has never been seen in EXÂ HyaÂ in quiescence, but its occurrence in outburst confirms the prediction in PaperÂ 1. However, some scepticism is in order since the X-ray data cover only âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,4.5 cycles of the 3.5-hr beat period. One might also be concerned that since the spacecraft orbital period is near EXÂ Hyaâ€™s orbital period (96 vs 98 mins), beating with the spacecraft orbit might explain the peak seen. However, this would produce equal peaks at Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omegaâ€‰-ADDOP:minus-â€‰Î©rxtesubscriptÎ©rxteOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start rxte POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm rxte} and Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omegaâ€‰+â€‰Î©rxtesubscriptÎ©rxteOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start rxte POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm rxte} whereas there is no power at Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omegaâ€‰+â€‰Î©rxtesubscriptÎ©rxteOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start rxte POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm rxte}.

By fitting a sinusoid to the three sections of 2â€“15 â€‰keVÂ X-ray data we find that the spin pulse had a modulation depth (semi-amplitude/mean) of 52%Â in the first section, declining to 25%Â in the second section and 5%Â in the third (the errors are dominated by flickering, and the first result is particularly unreliable since the data cover only âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,1 cycle). For comparison, Rosen etâ€‰al.Â (1991) quote a 14%Â depth in quiescent GingaÂ data over a similar energy range; thus the pulse amplitude was markedly bigger during outburst. There was no apparent change in pulse phase during the RXTEÂ observations.

The spectral changes over the spin cycle are consistent with the usual quiescent behaviour â€” greater modulation at lower energies â€” but the difficulty of disentangling (in a limited dataset) two periodicities, considerable flickering, and the outburst decline, made further investigation unreliable.

The X-ray data show the expected narrow, partial eclipse (not shown), with a profile similar to that of the quiescent eclipse. It is close to the time predicted by the ephemeris of Hellier &Â Sproats (1992; not including the sinusoidal term), being early by 40â€‰Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pmâ€‰10 s (0.007 in phase). Other than this, there was no orbital modulation.

div.p: We obtained Rğ‘…italic-RR-band photometry with the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory 0.9-m telescope over 5 nights of the decline and return to quiesence (Figs.Â 3 &Â 5).

The spin pulse is present throughout the dataset, but with different amplitudes (the semi-amplitudes/mean, as far as can be told given the flickering, are 12, 13, 24, 10 and 7 per cent on the five nights respectively). Reinsch &Â Beuermann (1990) also report the pulsation throughout their outburst dataset, with an amplitude comparable to that in quiescence.

It might appear from Fig.Â 5 that the pulse is late compared to the predicted times of maxima (which use the quadratic ephemeris of Hellier &Â Sproats 1992) but the situation is more complex: Fig.Â 6 shows that X-ray maximum occurs where predicted (to within 0.05 in phase) but that the optical pulse remains bright for âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,0.15 longer. This effect has not been reported previously, but this is the first simultaneous optical/X-ray dataset.

div.p: Since interpreting the eclipse profiles during outburst will be crucial, weâ€™ll first take a detour into the quiescent lightcurve. Note, firstly, that the partial, flat-bottomed X-ray eclipse implies that the secondary limb grazes the white dwarf, eclipsing the lower accreting pole but leaving the upper pole uneclipsed (Beuermann &Â Osborne 1988; Rosen etâ€‰al.Â 1991; Mukai etâ€‰al.Â 1998).

div.p: To investigate the quiescent optical eclipse we have used the 45 h of Bğµitalic-BB-band photometry reported by Sterken etâ€‰al.Â (1983) and Sterken &Â Vogt (1995). We first folded the data on the 67-min spin period (using 50 phase bins) to obtain the mean pulse profile. We then removed the pulse by subtracting from each datapoint the value of the mean pulse profile at that phase. Then we folded the data on the orbital cycle, to obtain the curve displayed in Fig.Â 7. The â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰30 per cent optical eclipse lasts for 3 mins and is coincident with the X-ray eclipse. Detailed studies (e.g.Â Siegel etâ€‰al.Â 1989) show that the eclipse centroid depends on spin phase and reveal that most of the eclipsed light arises from the accretion curtain of material falling onto the lower pole of the white dwarf.

Fig.Â 7 also shows an orbital hump extending between phases â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰0.6â€“0.15, and is presumably caused by the bright spot where the stream hits the accretion disc. Similar features are seen in dwarf novae such as ZÂ Cha, where the hump extends between phases 0.62â€“0.13 (Wood etâ€‰al.Â 1986).

figure.figcaption: Figure 7: The average quiescent orbital modulation from 45 h of Bğµitalic-BB-band photometry. The data are repeated, displaced downwards by 200 counts/sec, and with a smoothed orbital hump added to guide the eye.

div.p: By analogy with ZÂ Cha, we would also expect to see a disc eclipse and a bright spot eclipse. However, the disc eclipse involves only 23 per cent of the light in ZÂ Cha (Wood etâ€‰al.Â 1986), and in the grazing eclipse of EXÂ Hya the fraction might be lower. It is possible that the EXÂ Hya light curve contains a disc eclipse of â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰10 per cent depth, which starts at phase 0.95 as a steepening of the hump decline, and finishes at phase â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰0.05. It is also possible that the â€˜shoulderâ€™ to the eclipse, ending at â‰ˆRELOP:approximately-equals\approxâ€‰0.07, involves the eclipse of the bright spot. However, both interpretations are near the margins of the data quality given the flickering.

figure.figcaption: Figure 8: The eclipse profiles from the third night of CTIO photometry phased relative to the X-ray eclipse (crosses are from the first cycle, squares from the second). The solid dots are a model eclipse of a bright stream. Much of the out-of-eclipse variability is related to the spin cycle.

div.p: Since the evidence for a disc eclipse is marginal we can ask whether EXÂ Hya contains a disc at all, especially given the proposed models of discless accretion in IPs (Wynn &Â King 1995) and in EXÂ Hya in particular (King &Â Wynn 1999). The other evidence for a disc can be summarised as (see Hellier 1991 for a fuller account): (1) the dominance of the spin period, rather than the beat period, in quiescent X-ray lightcurves, which implies that the accreting material circularizes and loses knowledge of orbital phase; (2) a weak â€˜rotational disturbanceâ€™ seen in the emission lines (PaperÂ 2); (3) an emission-line S-wave with the correct phase and velocity to arise from an impact at the edge of a disc (PaperÂ 2); (4) the orbital hump and its being at the same phase as in ZÂ Cha (above); (5) material above the plane consistent with a splash where the stream hits the disc edge, revealed by soft X-ray and EUV dips (CÃ³rdova, Mason &Â Kahn 1985; Mauche 1999), and (6) the double-peaked lines seen in quiescence (PaperÂ 2);

Note, though, that none of these secure the velocity field of the disc, and so donâ€™t rule out a magnetically threaded structure (e.g.Â King &Â Wynn 1999) if it is able to mimic a disc in the above respects. We leave the issue of whether the outburst was a disc instability, thus implying the presence of a disc, to the discussion.

In the last night of photometry (when EXÂ HyaÂ was back in quiescence) the observed eclipse was narrow, V-shaped, coincident with the X-ray eclipse, and similar to previous quiescent eclipses (SectionÂ 4). On the penultimate night (JD 245â€‰1038) the eclipse egress had a â€˜shoulderâ€™ lasting until phase 0.07. The night before, both eclipses had asymmetrical V shapes with minima at phase 0.02 (relative to the X-ray mid-eclipse). Earlier still in the outburst the eclipse is difficult to discern: some shallow dips may be eclipses, but there is not enough repeatability in consecutive cycles to distinguish them from flickering. Similarly, near the peak of the 1987 outburst Reinsch &Â Beuermann (1990) saw broad, shallow dips that may be eclipses, but again there were not enough cycles to be sure.

The lateness of the eclipses on the third night (JD 245â€‰1037) implies that they are probably eclipses of an accretion stream rather than a disc. To test this we have computed the eclipse of a model stream, assuming it to have a constant brightness along the freefall trajectory between the initial impact with the disc and the point of its closest approach to the white dwarf. Fig.Â 8 shows that the model stream eclipse exhibits the same features (V shape, minimum at phase 0.02, faster ingress, slower egress) as the two eclipses observed on that night. The only free parameter is the model normalization, where in order to match the data we have diluted the stream with uneclipsed light such that the stream is 43%Â of the total [for comparison, in AMÂ Her stars the stream is commonly found to contribute 50â€“60%Â of the total light (Harrop-Allin etâ€‰al.Â 1999)]. Fig.Â 9 illustrates the geometry of the above model, showing the system at phases 0.00 (white dwarf eclipse), 0.02 (stream-eclipse minimum) and 0.07 (see below).

On the fourth night (JD 245â€‰1038) the eclipse is of the white dwarf and its environs, with an additional shoulder lasting until phase 0.07 (unfortunately we only have one cycle that night so canâ€™t check the featureâ€™s repeatability). The constant intensity during the shoulder implies an eclipse of a pointlike source. If this source is located along the track of the accretion stream, the start and end phases of the shoulder and the depth would be reproduced if it emitted 22%Â of the systemâ€™s light and was 0.29ağ‘italic-aa from the white dwarf (where ağ‘italic-aa is the stellar separation).

The (not particularly reliable) estimate of PaperÂ 2 is different, at 6â€‰Ã—109absentsuperscript109MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:9 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\times 10^{9}â€‰cm. However, we can check the plausibility by estimating the field strength that would place the magnetosphere there. Using the standard theory for a disc (e.g.Â Frank, King &Â Raine 1992) we find that for an accretion rate of 101616FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:16 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{16}â€‰gâ€‰s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}Â the implied magnetic moment is 9â€‰Ã—1032absentsuperscript1032MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:32 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\times 10^{32}â€‰Gâ€‰cm33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\mbox{{\scriptsize 3}}}, an order of magnitude greater than other estimates (e.g.Â PaperÂ 2; Warner 1996). One could argue that a stream would penetrate further in than a disc, increasing the derived magnetic moment further, although if the stream carried only a fraction of the accretion flow this would reduce the estimate again.

Is the distance then the radius of the outer disc edge? Again, it is inconsistent with PaperÂ 2, which found a value of 2.3â€‰Ã—1010absentsuperscript1010MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\times 10^{10}â€‰cm from the extent in phase of the rotational disturbance during the eclipse, and also from the separation of the double peaks in the emission lines, assuming these to give the Keplerian velocity at the disc edge. However, the extent of the rotational disturbance is hard to estimate, and the assumption of Keplerian motion could well be wrong. Further uncertainties are that an enhanced stream might penetrate into the disc, and also that the disc size might change in outburst, enlarging due to the enhanced viscosity of a disc instability but shrinking due to the addition of low-angular-momentum material from an enhanced stream.

Note, though, that the egress at phase 0.07 is consistent with a possible bright-spot egress at that phase in the quiescent lightcurve; thus, overall the most likely conclusion is that the feature is at the disc edge, and that previous estimates of the disc radius were too large.

Several features of EXÂ Hyaâ€™s outbursts are unlike those expected from a disc instability (SectionÂ 2). The most striking is the rarity of the outbursts. Over time, only 4%Â of EXÂ Hyaâ€™s accretion occurs during outburst (assuming, simplisticly, that the accretion rate scales as the optical flux). In contrast, the figure for a typical dwarf nova such as SSÂ Cyg is 90%. Another peculiarity is the range of interoutburst intervals, from 8 d to >RELOP:greater-than>â€‰2 y, when there is no change in quiescent magnitude (and hence mass-transfer rate). Note also the decline times: the 2â€“3 d declines are typical of dwarf novae and are comparable with the viscous timescale of a disc, but the 5-hr decline is not (even if allowance is made for the lack of inner disc). Further, the emission line equivalent widths increase during outburst (PaperÂ 1); in dwarf novae (with the exception of IPÂ Peg) they decrease.

In contrast, the evidence for an enhanced mass-transfer stream is clear. High-velocity line wings from an overflowing stream hitting the magnetosphere have been observed in both the 1987 and 1991 outbursts (PaperÂ 1; Buckley &Â Schwarzenberg-Czerny 1993). They were accompanied by greatly enhanced line emission from the stream impact at the edge of the disc. An X-ray beat period, caused by the stream connecting to the magnetic field and predicted in PaperÂ 1, has now been seen (SectionÂ 3.1). Lastly, the eclipse profiles during late decline reveal a bright overflowing stream (SectionÂ 5).

The above suggests that EXÂ Hyaâ€™s outbursts are mass transfer events, rather than disc instabilities, but is not conclusive. The disc-instability enthusiast could argue that the instabilities are reduced in duration and frequency by the magnetic disruption of the inner disc (Angelini &Â Verbunt 1989). If they are reduced to minor perturbations on the disc, the irregularity of the outbursts could follow. The enhanced mass transfer might then be a consequence of a disc instability, triggered by enhanced irradiation of the secondary star. This is easier in a magnetic system than in a dwarf nova since radiation from the magnetic poles is less likely to be hidden by the disc, compared to radiation from a boundary layer. There is indeed increased line emission from the secondary in the 1987 outburst, in addition to the increased line emission from the stream/bright-spot (PaperÂ 1).

In principle the optical eclipse profiles early in the outburst should tell us whether the disc has gone into a high state, however the difficulty of judging which features are real, given the flickering and limited data, precludes a firm conclusion. The first two nights of our optical dataset, and also the dataset early in an outburst by Reinsch &Â Beuermann (1990) are compatible with broad dips, âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,20 per cent deep, at the expected eclipse times. If a disc were the only light source, the grazing eclipse would produce dips of âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\,30 per cent depth, so the observed depth is consistent with some dilution by light from the magnetosphere (which must be present given the spin pulse). The broad dips might also be centered slightly late, compared to the expected eclipse time (Reinsch &Â Beuermann 1990, and also upper panel of our Fig.Â 5), which would indicate a contribution from an enhanced stream.

The absence, early in the outburst, of the narrow eclipses seen in quiescence is puzzling. It indicates either that the white dwarf and its accretion curtains are relatively faint (but why then do we still see a spin pulse?) or that in outburst we see predominantly the upper (uneclipsed) accretion curtain (but why is this?).
In summary, there is clearly enhanced mass transfer, but we cannot be sure whether or not this is triggered by a disc-instability outburst.

(1) EXÂ Hyaâ€™s outbursts are unlike those of any other dwarf novae. However, it is possible that they are characteristic of disc instabilities in a magnetically truncated disc rather than the result of a different process.

(2) There is clearly enhanced mass transfer in outburst. The evidence includes an enhanced stream/disc impact, eclipse profiles resulting from a bright stream overflowing the disc, line emission from where the overflowing stream hits the magnetosphere, and an X-ray periodicity at the beat period, indicating coupling of the overflowing stream to the magnetosphere.

(3) It is unclear whether the enhanced mass transfer is triggered by a disc instability. The eclipse profiles early in outburst are consistent with a brightened disc, but there isnâ€™t enough repeatability over different cycles to distinguish them from flickering with certainty.

(4) After reviewing the evidence we conclude that EXÂ Hya does possess an accretion disc, or a circulating structure with very similar characteristics. The optical orbital modulation in quiescence is similar to that of non-magnetic dwarf novae, including an orbital hump and marginal evidence for eclipses of the disc and bright spot.
(5) We find evidence that previous estimates for the disc size are too large, prefering instead a disc radius of 0.29 of the stellar separation.

(6) In possessing an overflowing stream giving rise to distorted emission line wings and distorted eclipse profiles, EXÂ HyaÂ in outburst shows some of the characteristics of SWÂ Sex stars (e.g.Â Hellier 1999).
